p: Cases of notifiable conditions must meet standard case definitions. In the USA, these case definitions are developed and updated in collaboration with the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists and CDC. The 2012 hepatitis C surveillance case definitions require a combination of symptoms and laboratory findings for acute disease and laboratory findings only for past/present hepatitis C [ 9]. Because the clinical characteristics are the same for acute hepatitis A, B, and C, laboratory testing is needed to identify the specific viral cause of illness. For both acute and past/present hepatitis C cases, laboratory findings include a positive antibody to hepatitis C virus screening test, nucleic acid test for HCV RNA, and genotype testing. A special definition is applied to identify new seroconversions that require only one positive test and a previous negative test within the past 6 months [ 9].
